_exec_summary.SummaryText:
This is an executive summary of the policies, procedures and activities for compliance with the EPA's Accidental Release Prevention Requirements - Risk Management Program pursuant to 40 CFR 68 for 3M Company's Springfield facility.

 

The accidental release prevention and emergency response policies at the stationary source [40 CFR 68.155(a)]:



The accidental release prevention and emergency response policies are addressed in the individual RMP/PSM procedures which detail the RMP / PSM program requirements as well as how 3M Company will comply with the applicable requirements. The site is not a responding facility for releases of the RMP listed chemicals, so the site utilizes an Emergency Action Plan.

  

The stationary source and regulated substances handled [40 CFR 68.155(b)]:



The Springfield facility manufactures adhesive systems for use in a wide variety of products from aerosols to structural adhesive films. The facility has five (5) regulated substances in quantities regulated by EPA's Risk Management Program. 3M employees are trained and experienced in working with these substances, and 3M contributes to safety by providing high quality manufacturing processes, equipment, and maintenance. 



The following processes and associated regulated chemicals are used at Springfield - 3M Company for the manufacturing of semi-finished and finished products: 



     Bulk Storage Tank (Level 1 - Toxic)

?         Toluene diisocyanate (26471-62-5)

     Bulk Tank and Containers (Level 3 - Flammable) 

?         Pentane (109-66-0)

?         Propane (74-98-6)

?         Dimethylether (115-10-6)

?         Isobutane (75-28-5)



The general accidental release prevention program and chemical-specific prevention steps [40 CFR 68.155(c)]:



For the Bulk Tank and Containers process, the Springfield facility has implemented the Program Level 3 prevention program requirements under the RMP regulations.  The required elements of the RMP prevention program are listed below:



-  Employee Part

icipation

-  Process Safety Information

-  Process Hazard Analysis

-  Operating Procedures

-  Contractors

-  Pre-startup Safety Review

-  Mechanical Integrity

-  Hot Work Permit

-  Management of Change

-  Incident Investigation

-  Emergency Planning and Response

-  Compliance Audits



These items, their specific requirements, and how the Springfield facility will comply with the requirements are addressed in the individual procedural documents.



The five-year accident history [40 CFR 68.155(d)]:



The Springfield facility has had zero RMP reportable incidents in the previous five years.



The emergency response program [40 CFR 68.155(e)]:



In the event of an emergency, the Springfield facility will notify the Greene County LEPC and the local fire departments to respond and will evacuate their employees when needed.  Additional details related to emergency procedures are located in the facility's emergency action plan.



Planned changes to improve safety [40 CFR 68.155(f)]:



The facility completed a process hazard analysis (PHA) on the Pentane Tank 7/27/2017 and the Propellant Tanks 8/24/2017 which identified several recommendations for enhanced process safety.  These recommendations are summarized in the PHA report and are currently under evaluation.



The Springfield facility develops an annual Environmental, Health, and Safety Plan (EHS Plan) utilizing sources of data such as Injury and Illness Records, Incident Investigation Reports and Incident Rates, Operational Improvement and Safety Suggestions, Safety Tours, Audit Findings, and Self Assessments. 



A yearly analysis is conducted to prioritize issues extracted from the data sources. Action items are then developed, including target completion dates and assignments to individuals and teams. The resulting EHS Plan is approved by 3M Springfield and corporate management teams.
